Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Willow AGEP Alliance: A Model to Advance Native American STEM Faculty

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Montana, Salish Kootenai College, and Sitting Bull College will collaborate in the Willow Alliance to develop, implement, and study a model for the professional success of STEM instructional faculty and staff who are enrolled in, or descendants of, Native American tribes. This alliance was created in response to the Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program solicitation (NSF 16-552) The AGEP program seeks to advance knowledge about models to improve pathways to the professoriate and success of historically underrepresented minority (URM) graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty in specific STEM disciplines and/or STEM education research fields. AGEP Transformation Alliances develop, replicate or reproduce; implement and study, via integrated educational and social science research, models to transform the dissertator phase of doctoral education, postdoctoral training and/or faculty advancement, and the transitions within and across the pathway levels, of URMs in STEM and/or STEM education research careers.

Recent reports indicate that only 700 Native American science and engineering doctoral degree holders are employed full time in our nation's universities and colleges. Universities and colleges are endeavoring to recruit, retain, and promote Native American STEM faculty who serve as role models and academic leaders for Native American students to learn from, to work with, and to emulate in order to address the STEM achievement gap between native and non-native undergraduate and graduate students in our nation. The Willow AGEP Alliance has the potential to advance a model to improve the success and retention of Native Americans in instructional STEM faculty positions, contributing to native STEM role models for native STEM undergraduate and graduate students at postsecondary academic institutions.

The Willow AGEP Alliance plans to develop, implement, and study a model for the professional success of Native American STEM faculty. Participants include Native American STEM faculty working at one of the three partnering colleges. The project includes three intervention components in the model: a mentoring program; grant preparation and management training activities; and an institutional support program, which focuses on retention efforts. The integrated qualitative research will examine the personal, relational, and collective experiences of the native STEM instructional faculty and staff that enhance or inhibit professional development and career advancement; examine the underlying institutional issues affecting promotion and advancement; examine the approaches the faculty and staff use to increase promotion and advancement; examine the how different types of universities and colleges (tribal vs. non-tribal) support Native American STEM instructional faculty and staff; and examine the climate of STEM departments to compare how non-native STEM instructional faculty and staff and native STEM instructional faculty and staff experience professional development, promotion and advancement. The formative and summative evaluation plan follows an indigenous evaluation framework. There is an advisory board for feedback to the team, and a dissemination plan to include sharing with other tribal colleges and non-tribal universities in Montana, North Dakota, Idaho and Washington.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Willow Alliance?s main goal is to develop, implement, and study a model for the professional success of Native American faculty in STEM (NAF-STEM). Sitting Bull College (SBC) was an equal partner of the Alliance with University of Montana and Salish Kootenai College and contributed to the initial model development, implementation, and study.

  • Model development included the Institutional Support Program (ISP) which aims to develop policies and best practices to help institutions increase the success and retention of NAF-STEM. ISP included interviews and discussions with NAF-STEM, review of policies and practices at mainstream institutions and tribal colleges and universities (TCUs), and interviews with administrators at these institutions.
  • Model implementation included the Indigenous Mentoring Program (IMP) and Research Publication and Grant Preparation Program (RPGP). IMP interviewed NAF-STEM about mentoring experiences and provided mentoring opportunities. The RPGP offered NAF-STEM grant writing workshops, structured grant proposal or manuscript writing time, and a collaborative writing project focused on NAF-STEM professional experiences.
  • Model study included examining development and implementation activities and regular re-examination of the entire model. The Social Science Research (SSR) component analyzed data from NAF-STEM to identify factors that affect their professional success. This data was shared with the other components. SSR also conducted a national institutional climate survey of NAF-STEM. Further study and refinement of the model involves applying feedback and suggestions from an external evaluation team, NAF-STEM participants, and advisory boards.

 

A group of NAF-STEM from the Alliance institutions participated in interviews, workshops, networking, peer mentorship, and discussions throughout the entire project. Specific activities these participants were offered included grant writing workshops, peer mentoring, conference attendance for networking and mentoring, and annual Willow Alliance workshops. Through mentoring and sharing experiences and viewpoints these NAF-STEM participants developed a community and relationships among the Alliance institutions that were largely absent due to institutional barriers. Through participation in the model components like the IMP and SSR, NAF-STEM shared concerns and ideas for changing how mainstream institutions and TCUs can advocate and support Indigenous approaches to research, scholarship, and teaching.

The Alliance implemented an authorship protocol to be inclusive and respectful of NAF-STEM?s knowledge contributions. NAF-STEM were invited to co-author manuscripts based on narratives and data they provided. This allowed the Alliance to practice respect and reciprocity. And, NAF-STEM learned more about the research and methodologies used to study their contributions. This authorship protocol will be shared with the wider STEM and social science disciplines and could change existing definitions of authorships in academia. 

Model implementation and development components can be adapted by institutions seeking to better support NAF-STEM and increase their retention, participation, and success. The IMP shows those involved in faculty professional development ways to offer more mentorship opportunities and increase cultural sensitivity. RPGP activities can be adapted by institutions to provide more targeted professional development for NAF-STEM pursuing grant funding and research collaborations. The ISP will provide potential policies, best practices, and recommendations on how to strengthen support of NAF-STEM and other minority faculty and offer better understanding of challenges commonly shared by underrepresented faculty members.

The Alliance incorporated the 6Rs (Respect, Relevance, Responsibility, Reciprocity, Representation, and Relationship) and other aspects of Indigenous Research Methodologies (IRM) in establishing a framework to increase success of NAF-STEM. Educational institutions could adopt specific Willow model components and adapt the 6Rs to their institutional contexts to increase the success of NAF-STEM in various ways. The Alliance?s use of IRM shows its strengths and how IRM can be used in both STEM and non-STEM disciplines. The Alliance will report in publications how the IRM was used. These dissemination efforts will show the motivations of Indigenous researchers using these approaches and increase understanding of IRM among STEM and non-STEM researchers.

The results have shown that NAF-STEM have definitions of success that differ from non-Native researchers. Furthermore, Indigenous pathways of knowledge production differ from those in Western science. The division between these ways of knowing and ideas of success can act as agents to discredit and undervalue the contributions and progression toward an Indigenous research methodology for STEM. Further analysis of current and future data will provide more information on how institutions can better increase the success of NAF-STEM and better support NAF-STEM who use Indigenous research methods and knowledge production.

In addition to disseminating findings through research presentations and publications, the Alliance will continue working with institutional leaders, specifically at the Alliance institutions, to share information about the findings and Willow model. Plans include working with Alliance institutions to adapt components of the IMP, RPGP, and ISP. The Alliance plans to work with University of Montana to adapt the IMP to the university?s professional development program. Plans exist to develop a RPGP handbook and make it available to the Alliance institutions. And, there will be continued work with institutional leaders on ISP?s best practices and policies for adaptation.
